td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

td.p: We are in the process of developing and testing our Digital Learning Plan. We are not creating online classes, we are working on delivering our curriculum in a digital format. Educating your children is the most important thing that we do each and every day and we do not take this lightly. Making this change as an educator does not happen overnight and we want to make sure that we are providing the best opportunity for a quality education for your children.

As we move forward, this area will contain weekly plans for students for each grade level Kindergarten through Grade 12. Our digital learning plan will be starting on April 6. Please see the grading procedures as they pertain to this time out of school due to the COVID-19 School Closure in the letter in the column on the right side of this page.

Teachers have started posting information and videos into Google Classroom (grades 3 -12), SeeSaw (grades 1 and 2 ) and Kindergarten (Google Site). Encourage your students to start going into their classrooms to become familiar with how to use the site and practice the tools. Please keep checking this webpage for more information.

Our teachers will be available throughout the school day to answer questions via email or through the digital platform they are using for their classes. Remember that they may be teaching, providing feedback to students or working on new content, so they will get back to you as soon as possible. Each teacher has established OFFICE HOURS each day when they will be immediately available to answer questions. Please click on this link for each teacher's office hours.

p.em: April 20th - April 24th (Please click on each grade/class for this week's Learning Menu.)

td.p: To see previous week's Learning Menus, click on this link. You can also click on the Page to the left titled Previous Learning Menus.

This site, created by Mrs. Konen and Ms. Pospychala, is a resource for students and parents. It contains weekly lessons for 4k-2 and 3-4 under the students tab. There is a virtual tranquility tab which contains many videos and activities for body regulation and mindfulness. Our check in forms for every school level are also is a tab. There is also a parent resource tab. Take a few moments to check it out by clicking on this link.

span.style: background-color: transparent; color: rgb(103, 103, 103); font-size: 1.25em; font-style: italic; font-weight: 400;

td.p: Dear School District of Hilbert families,

The health and safety of our students and staff are always our number one priority. We are closing our school buildings under order from the State of Wisconsin to help contain the spread of COVID-19, the coronavirus in Wisconsin. We know that keeping children at home may cause difficulties for your children and families as you juggle work, child care and other challenges, and our staff are committed to doing everything we can to help make this as positive an experience as possible for your children.

Gov. Tony Evers on March 13, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, from Wednesday, March 18 to April 5, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain COVID-19. The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state - and adds Wisconsin to a growing list of states to close schools. On Tuesday, March 17, 2020, he changed the closure to indefinitely. We will continue to update this webpage as more information is released.

“Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care," Evers said. "We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”
The School District of Hilbert will be closed from Tuesday, March 17 until further notice. All after-school activities and athletics, including practices, will be canceled during this closure period.

span.span: Starting on Wednesday, April 1, 2020, the School District of Hilbert will provide meals to all interested students in a grab-and-go format. Pick up will occur at the Main Office doors on Monday-Friday from 11:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. If you have any questions regarding this program, please call 920-853-3558 and ask for Lori Ott, Food Service Director.

td.p: Some internet carriers are offering free and/or low cost options that your family may be able to use.
See DPI list of internet offers for families

Spectrum is offering free broadband internet and WiFi access for 60 days to families with K-12 and college students. Charter, which operates Spectrum internet, said they will also waive installation fees for new households. Learn more about the Spectrum offer here or call 844-488-8395.
Comcast Internet Essentials indicated that they are providing 60 days of free internet to qualifying families. Learn more about the Comcast offer.

For students with Special Education needs, please contact our Special Education Coordinator, Christina DeMarco at 920-853-3558 or demarcoc@hilbertk12.org, the Middle High School Principal, Nathan Wesener at 920-853-558558 or wesenern@hilbertk12.org or the Elementary Principal, Amy Schmitz at 920-853-3558 or schmitza@hilbertk12.org.

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact the school 920-853-3558 to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

p.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in the School District of Hilbert at this time.

td.p: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Calumet County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin - in Dane, Fond Du Lac, Milwaukee, Outagamie, Pierce, Racine, Sheboygan, Waukesha, Winnebago and Wood counties. Another 37 WI residents returned March 16 from a cruise where they may have been exposed and will be self-quarantined for 14 days.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: The School District of Hilbert has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.
td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.

td.p: This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic, the President and Governor declaring it a public health emergency and the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13 on all travel from Europe, including the UK and Ireland, to the U.S.
td.div: The state of Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS) is asking schools and organizations to:

ul.li: not gather in groups of 10 people or more
Avoid traveling to areas in the US with sustained community transmission of COVID-19 (currently Washington, New York, and California). See map of US sustained community transmission of COVID-19.
Self-quarantine for 14 days upon return for anyone who travels to any U.S. states with confirmed community spread of COVID-19.

td.p: Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country or area in the United States with a Level 2 or 3 travel health notice, please contact the School District of Hilbert at 920-853-3558 before returning to school. The CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days. Read more about travel on the CDC's website.

We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students’ safety first. If you have any questions, reach out to me at 920-853-3558 or sweeret@hilbertk12.org.
